body:
<https://sw.kovidgoyal.net/kitty/keyboard-protocol/>

- [x] Enable kitty's keyboard protocol #18181
- [x] Recognize keys in private use area #19180
- [x] Recognize <kbd>Super</kbd> modifier #24357
- [ ] Add notations for keys and modifiers not yet present in Nvim?
- [ ] Enable higher progressive enhancement levels?

comment_data.body: Probably related: #2204
https://github.com/neovim/neovim/issues/5916 seems higher-leverage. Marking this as `unplanned` therefore.
There are also two issues regarding `modifyOtherKeys` (#14350 and #15352) that may be related to this issue.
foot started implementing this protocol: https://codeberg.org/dnkl/foot/pulls/811

This issue has been mentioned on **Neovim Discourse**. There might be relevant details there:

https://neovim.discourse.group/t/nitty-gritty-questions-on-terminal-nvim-and-keyboard-events/1624/1

With the improvements around distinguishing ambiguous keys in the 0.7 release, how much would need to be done to support the first level of the kitty keyboard protocol ("disambiguate escape codes")? Would it just be sending the correct CSI codes to the terminal (`CSI > 1u` and `CSI < u` to push and pop state, and `CSI ? u` to query support)? Or would it be more involved?
It is a bit tricky to encode new modifiers, especially if considering backward-compatibility.
Could neovim just ignore modifiers it doesn't recognize?

Yes of course, how it converts the key events from the terminal to its own internal key
event representation is entirely up to it.
Would be great to see support for say, <kbd>Hyper</kbd> in Neovim with Kitty.

> With the improvements around distinguishing ambiguous keys in the 0.7 release, how much would need to be done to support the first level of the kitty keyboard protocol ("disambiguate escape codes")? Would it just be sending the correct CSI codes to the terminal (`CSI > 1u` and `CSI < u` to push and pop state, and `CSI ? u` to query support)? Or would it be more involved?

https://github.com/neovim/neovim/pull/18181
Thank you @gpanders !

This isn't fully supported yet. libtermkey only supports <kbd>Shift</kbd>, <kbd>Alt</kbd>, and <kbd>Ctrl</kbd> modifers, while kitty supports much more, including <kbd>Super</kbd> and <kbd>Hyper</kbd>.

One thing I noticed, not sure where to put it, that the differentiation between `<Tab>` and `<C-i>` only exists in normal mode and not in insert mode.

I tried:
```vim
imap <TAB> hello
imap <C-i> test
```
Only one of them is in effect for both key presses.

But in normal mode
```vim
nmap <TAB> dd
nmap <C-i> yy
```
works as expected.

> One thing I noticed, not sure where to put it, that the differentiation between `<Tab>` and `<C-i>` only exists in normal mode and not in insert mode.
> 
> I tried:
> 
> ```viml
> imap <TAB> hello
> imap <C-i> test
> ```
> 
> Only one of them is in effect for both key presses.

This shouldn't happen.

I think my report was invalid, I forgot to test with `-u NONE`, with it, it works correctly.

The problem seamed to be my auto complete plugin that was not correctly mapping when not currently completing.
Therefor not a neovim bug, but a bug on their side.

I am not able to get this functionality. I have:

```vim
nnoremap <C-e> :echomsg('unshifted e')<CR>
nnoremap <C-S-e> :echomsg('shifted E')<CR>
nnoremap g<C-e> ge
nnoremap g<C-S-e> gE
```

The distinction is correctly made in the plain (echomsg) case, but not in the chord (g) case. In particular, it works for `g<C-e>`, but nothin happens for `g<C-S-e>`

I am using Kitty 0.26.3, Nvim 0.8.0

Thanks in advance!

By the way, would implementing this protocol finally allow you to set left and right modifier keys separately?

It seems not natively as the protocol is unfortunately not planning to support that per

https://github.com/kovidgoyal/kitty/issues/6169
It won't afaict; but it should allow you to set shortcuts to bindings like Cmd+C etc, which is not currently natively supported
<kbd>Super</kbd> is supported as of #24357. <kbd>Hyper</kbd> will be a bit complicated to support.

> By the way, would implementing this protocol finally allow you to set left and right modifier keys separately?

from what I've tried, the protocol does support it in the form of sending separate presses of the modifiers themselves (for example: `57447` for right and `57441` for left shift) which would need internal state holding from the program side, but it does send it - try `\033[>11u`.
@MartyMcFlyInTheSky the checklist at the top of the issue indicates the state. Ask usage questions on https://github.com/neovim/neovim/discussions , any more comments will be deleted here.

milestone.description: Low priority items. We plan to work on this but don't have a target date.
milestone.title: backlog

title: TUI: kitty's keyboard protocol support

type.description: A request, idea, or new functionality
type.name: Enhancement
